Phase transformation and electronic structure modulation of 1T-MoS2 with electronegative non-metal doping as anode material for enhanced potassium-ion battery Foysal Kabir Tareq Writing – review & editing Supervision Software Project administration Conceptualization 1 ⁎ Md Iftekher Hossain Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Software Resources Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation 1 Souman Rudra Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Department of Engineering Sciences, University of Agder, Grimstad 4879, Norway Department of Engineering Sciences University of Agder Grimstad 4879 Norway Department of Engineering Sciences, University of Agder, Grimstad 4879, Norway ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract The study investigates 1T-MoS2 doped with electronegative atoms as a potential anode material for KIBs. It explores inherent complexities such as the impact of doping on electrical properties, phase transformation, thermodynamic stability, and battery-related electrochemical analysis. The scarcity and high cost of lithium resources drive the search for sustainable alternatives, positioning potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) as promising energy storage solutions due to the natural abundance and advantageous electrochemical properties of the potassium. This study investigates the enhancement of KIB anodes through phase transformation and electronic structure engineering of monolayer 1T-MoS2, achieved via doping with highly electronegative non-metal elements: carbon (C), nitrogen (N), oxygen (O), and fluorine (F). Density functional theory (DFT) simulations reveal that electronegative atom doping enhances phase stability, structural robustness, and thermal resilience, which are key properties for high-performance KIB anodes. Among the doped configurations, F and N-doped 1T-MoS2 (MoS2-F and MoS2-N) exhibit superior electrochemical performance, showing optimal adsorption energies and significantly improved electronic conductivity, attributable to favorable charge redistribution and increased active potassium adsorption sites. Specifically, MoS2-F and MoS2-N achieve the highest specific capacities of 339.65 and 339.17 mAh/g, respectively, while maintaining stability within an ideal open circuit voltage range, outperforming undoped MoS2. This work underscores the potential of electronegative atom doping in 1T-MoS2 to enable sustainable, high-capacity energy storage solutions, offering key advancements in the electrochemical and structural properties of KIB anodes. Keywords Molybdenum sulfide Electronegative elements Phase transformation Anode materials Potassium-ion battery 1 Introduction The global energy landscape is undergoing a dramatic transformation, shifting from fossil fuels to renewable and clean energy sources in response to the urgent threat of climate change. This transformation aligns with the United Nations' adoption of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in 2015, particularly the goal of “affordable and clean energy”, highlighting a collective commitment to sustainable renewable energy solutions [1]. However, the intermittent nature of renewable energy sources necessitates efficient energy storage systems for their seamless integration into power grids. Over the past two decades, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have gained widespread acceptance due to their extended cycle life, high energy density, and environmental compatibility [2–4]. Consequently, LIBs have emerged as the primary solution in the current energy storage landscape, extensively utilized for storing energy from renewables, fossil fuels, and other sources. Nevertheless, the future potential of LIBs is limited by the scarcity of lithium (Li) on Earth (0.0017% by weight), along with high costs, insufficient cyclability, and low energy density [5–8]. On the other hand, potassium-ion batteries (KIBs), which share similar working mechanisms to LIBs, are garnering significant interest as alternative, sustainable, and cost-effective energy storage systems, attributed to the abundance of potassium (K) in natural resources (2.09 wt%) [9]. The abundant reserves are accompanied with similar physicochemical characteristics, lower redox potential, and high energy density position KIBs as promising alternatives to LIBs [10]. Additionally, KIBs exhibit advantages over LIBs due to their weaker Lewis acidity, which facilitates improved charge transport [11]. However, the development of KIBs necessitates the exploration of new host materials with enhanced electrochemical performance compared to their lithium counterparts. In recent times, two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides (2D TMDs) have garnered increased attention as potential anode materials for alkali metal ion energy storage devices, stemming from their abundant adsorption sites and large surface area [12–14]. In contrast to graphite, a commonly used anode material in LIBs, 2D TMDs present a significant advantage as a result of their larger interlayer spacing, which renders them more suitable for the intercalation of electronegative ions [15]. Among the diverse range of 2D TMDs, 2D MoS2 has been the subject of extensive research for its potential applications in electrochemical energy conversion and storage [16,17]. Notably, the abundance of 2D MoS2 in nature further supports its potential for widespread adoption in energy storage devices [18]. On top of that, 2D MoS2 exhibits a variety of crystalline phases (2H, 3R, 1T, etc.) with distinct atomic configurations [19] enabling different possibilities to work with. Among these phases, the 2H configuration stands out as the most stable, prompting extensive investigation and research advancements. Initially, Fang et al. [20] first investigated the reversible insertion and extraction of Li+ ions into 2H-MoS2 and later Wang et al. [21] delved into the configurational changes of 2H-MoS2, revealing that extensive Li+ insertion could induce a phase transition from the 2H phase to the 1T phase. Shu et al. [22] further corroborated this phase transition through ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations at 300 K using density functional theory (DFT) calculations and this irreversible phase transition was finally experimentally validated by Wang et al. [23] demonstrating through the insertion of sodium ions into 2H-MoS2 limiting its suitability for long-term applications in energy storage devices. The phase transition sparked a shift in focus towards 1T-MoS2, coinciding with the study by Lane et al. [24] analyzing the stabilization energy of 1T-MoS2 and 2H-MoS2 during Li and Na insertion, revealing that the 1T phase became increasingly stable with Li/Na ion insertion, while the 2H phase became less stable. From another perspective, the thermodynamically stable and prevalent 2H phases of MoS2 demonstrate semiconductor properties and possess a sizable band gap, which are unfavorable for electronic conductivity. Despite numerous efforts to enhance conductivity by integrating with conductive carbon atoms [25], MoS2 nanostructures still grapple with their inherent low conductivity, hampering overall catalytic efficiency in electrochemical reactions. Conversely, the metallic nature of 1T phases in MoS2 provides an advantage in this regard as material conductivity plays a crucial role in determining its suitability as an anode, through enabling efficient electron flow. This phenomenon was scrutinized by Majid et al. [15] using comprehensive DFT calculations, which concluded that the 1T polytype demonstrates superior electrochemical performance due to its improved band structure and enhanced capacity for intercalated ions, as well as their mobility, thereby positioning it favorably compared to its 2H and 3R phase counterparts. However, the implementation of 1T-MoS2 as an anode is still plagued by several shortcomings, such as inadequate electronic conductivity, noticeable growth in volume coupled with vulnerability to stacking/restacking, leading to swift decline in capacity and diminished rate performance over repeated cycles [26]. Furthermore, He et al. [27] assert that the 1T-MoS2 monolayer exhibits inadequate adsorption characteristics, rendering it unsuitable for KIBs. As an answer to these shortcomings, strategies such as nanostructure engineering, integration with conductive materials, and elemental doping have emerged as viable approaches to enhance the electrochemical properties of MoS2-based electrode materials, especially for hydrogen evolution reactions [28,29]. Despite these advancements, there remains a significant gap in the exploration of doped configurations incorporating highly electronegative atoms within 1T-MoS2 as an anode host for KIBs, particularly in comparison to pristine 1T-MoS2. This underscores the crucial need for an in-depth theoretical comprehension of the anchoring impacts of K+ ion constituents on electronegative atom doped 1T-MoS2 for KIBs. This research delves into a comprehensive exploration of the potassium ion interaction mechanism within 1T-MoS2 monolayer doped with highly electronegative nonmetal atoms (hereafter represented as MoS2-D; where D = carbon (C), nitrogen (N), oxygen (O), and fluorine (F)) to increase active sites on the surface to enhance potassiation, serving as the anode material specifically for KIBs. We conducted an in-depth investigation into the principal electrochemical attributes, including geometrical configurations, electronic compositions, metal binding, and thermal stability of all the structures through DFT computations. Here we observed that, in comparison to the pristine structures, the doped structures demonstrate superior performance in terms of phase transition stability and thermal stability, making them a superior alternative to the pristine structure. Furthermore, the adsorption of K+ ions in the doped structures enhances conductivity for the cases of F and O doped structures, resulting in improved electronic conductivity, which is highly desirable for high-performance battery applications. However, upon evaluating the electrochemical properties that confirm the aptness of anodic materials, the examination of specific capacity and open circuit voltage (OCV) reveals that 1T-MoS2-F and 1T-MoS2-N not only surpass the other two counterparts but also outperform pristine 2D 1T-MoS2 as potential anodic components for KIBs. 2 Computational methods The atomic adsorption energy, bond lengths, bond angles, electronic properties, and charge transfer of pristine and 1T-MoS2, as well as K-intercalated pristine and doped 1T-MoS2, were investigated through cutting-edge DFT simulations utilizing Quantum Espresso software [30]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA), specifically the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional, has been opted for to elucidate the doping and hybridization between electrons and exchange-correlation functional [31,32] employing computational configurations presented in Fig. 1 (a). For calculation, 3 × 3 × 1 1T-MoS2 pristine and doped monolayer supercell has been built as geometry structure, comprising 27 atoms with a vacuum zone of 23 Å to prevent interlayer interaction. For occupations, Methfessel-Paxton smearing [33] with a smearing energy width of 0.02 Ry has been employed and the Brillouin zone of MoS2 monolayer configurations underwent sampling utilizing the Monkhorst Pack scheme [34], employing a grid of 12 × 12 × 1 for Self-Consistent Field (SCF) energy calculation and 18 × 18 × 1 for density of states (DOS) calculation. For the purpose of achieving computational convergence, the cut off energy has been set as 40 Ry with electronic convergence threshold of 1 × 10−6 Ry. It is noteworthy to mention that previous studies [35] have indicated the absence of discernible van der Waals (vdW) interlayer effects in monolayer MoS2. Consequently, vdW correction was omitted from the calculations involving non-adsorbent structures. The computational process began by validating the geometrical configurations and electronic properties of pristine 1T-MoS2 against existing experimental or reported data. After verifying and optimizing the computational parameters based on these benchmarks, subsequent calculations were conducted for the doped structures as summarized in Fig. 1(b). This enabled a thorough assessment of various atomic properties and their respective impacts on KIB performance. To assess the adsorption characteristics between K atoms in pristine and doped 1T-MoS2, the intercalation energy or the adsorption energy (E ads) for individual metal atoms on either the pristine 1T-MoS2 monolayer or within the doped 1T-MoS2 structure can be calculated as follows [27] (1) E a d s = E 1 T - M o S 2 - K - E 1 T - M o S 2 - E K E a d s ( d o p e d ) = E M o S 2 - D - K - E M o S 2 - D - E K where E 1 T - M o S 2 - K , E 1 T - M o S 2 , and E K reflect the associated energies involved with the K anchored MoS2 monolayer, pristine MoS2 monolayer, and metallic K bulk, respectively. Also, E M o S 2 - D - K and E M o S 2 - D refer to the same but for the doped structure. Additionally, to observe the structural stability of the studied materials loaded with K ions, cohesive energy (E coh) also needs to be calculated through the formula [36] (2) E c o h = E 1 T - M o S 2 - K - lE M o + mE S + nE K l + m + n E c o h ( d o p e d ) = E M o S 2 - D - K - [ lE M o + mE S + nE K + oE D ] l + m + n + o where E Mo, E S, and E D are the energies of isolated Mo, S, doped electronegative atom respectively. Also, l, m, n, and o refers to the number of Mo, S, K, and the electronegative doped atoms that are present in the monolayer under consideration. Also, the corresponding specific capacity (C M) of the studied materials structure can be calculated as [27,37]. (3) C M = znF M 1 T - M o S 2 C M ( d o p e d ) = znF M 1 T - M o S 2 - X where F stands for Faraday’s constant and M 1 T - M o S 2 and M M o S 2 - D refer to the mass of pristine and doped monolayers respectively. In order to observe the performances of the studied materials, OCV also needs to be calculated through the formula [27] (4) O C V = Δ E nze = E 1 T - M o S 2 - K - E 1 T - M o S 2 - E K nze O C V d o p e d = E M o S 2 - D - K - E M o S 2 - D - E K nze where n is the number of K atoms adsorbed on the monolayer surface, z is the electronic charge of adsorbed atom which is 1 in case of K and e stands for the electronic charge of electrons. Furthermore, formation energy (E f) for the adsorbed structures can be determined as [37] (5) E f = E 1 T - M o S 2 - K n - E 1 T - M o S 2 + nE K 1 + n E f ( d o p e d ) = E M o S 2 - D - K n - [ E M o S 2 - D + nE K ] 1 + n where, n represents the number of intercalated K ions on the monolayers. Ionic diffusion conductivities (σ) were determined by extrapolating the diffusivity obtained from AIMD simulations at room temperature using the Nernst-Einstein equation [38]. (6) σ = N q 2 D kT where D is the diffusion coefficient, N is the carrier density, q is the carrier charge, T is the absolute temperature, and k is the Boltzmann constant. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Geometric structures and electrical properties The optimized configurations of pristine and doped 1T-MoS2 monolayers and their lattice parameters are presented in Fig. 2 and Table 1 . Computational findings revealed that the structural lattice dimension of the optimized pristine 1T-MoS2 monolayer, illustrated in Fig. 2(a), is a = b = 3.227 Å and the bond length between Mo and S was measured to be 2.441 Å, while the bond angle of Mo–S–Mo was determined to be 83.371°. These findings are consistent with those reported in previous studies, thereby confirming the validity of our computational methodology [15,39–41]. As seen in Fig. 2(b–e), doping 1T-MoS2 with electronegative elements results in noticeable structural changes compared to pristine 1T-MoS2. These changes are influenced by the electronegativities of the dopant atoms, which not only lead to a contraction of the bond lengths between Mo and the dopant atoms but also alter the bond angles within the structure. This suggests that the introduction of more electronegative dopant atoms affects both bond length and bond angle, contributing to significant structural modifications of 1T-MoS2 upon doping. This phenomenon arises from the differences in electron affinities and electronegativities of the dopant atoms relative to S, which affect the distribution of electron density within the bond and consequently influence the bond length. The electronegativity of F, O, N, C, S, and Mo is 3.98, 3.44, 3.04, 2.55, 2.58, and 2.16, respectively. When a more electronegative dopant atom, such as F, O, N, or C, bonds with a less electronegative atom like Mo, polarization occurs, with the more electronegative atom attracting electron density towards itself. This polarization can result in a shorter bond length compared to a non-polarized bond. Thus, when analyzing bond lengths, the expected order of decreasing bond length correlates with ascending electronegativity, potentially resulting in bond lengths arranged as C > N > O > F. It is important to note that although F exhibits the highest electronegativity, its strong interactions may lead to shorter bond lengths due to increased polarization effects. In alignment with these expectations, the observations revealed a clear sequence in the bond lengths between the metal atoms and the electronegative atoms, as illustrated in Table 1. Specifically, F doping resulted in a bond length reduction to 1.871 Å, consistent with previous report [42]. This shortening of the bond length has led to changes in the adjacent bonds, as evidenced by the increased bond length of 2.478 Å between the doped atom affected Mo and sulfur S. Furthermore, the phenomenon of bond length reduction between Mo and the sequentially less electronegative atoms, O and N, is also apparent, with bond lengths of 2.116 and 2.276 Å for Mo–O and Mo–N, respectively [43]. A similar trend is also evident in the case of C, which is closest to S in terms of electronegativity, resulting in the smallest change in bond length to 2.323 Å for Mo–C. Additionally, the strength and stability of the bonds formed between Mo and the dopant atoms significantly affect the overall bond lengths within the system. To further assess this influence, we calculated the energy difference ( Δ E = E M o S 2 - D - E 1 T - M o S 2 ) between pristine 1T-MoS2 and its doped counterparts, serving as a measure of the relative stability of the doped structures. Fig. 3 (a) indicates that the MoS2-F has the highest structural stability ( Δ E = −336.61 eV), followed by MoS2-N (−241.63 eV). Conversely, positive Δ E for MoS2-C (78.96 eV) indicates that C-doped structure is less stable compared to pristine 1T-MoS2 and the system requires additional energy to form the doped structure, making it less energetically favorable. These variations in stability are directly linked to the nature of the dopant atoms and their interaction with the 1T-MoS2 framework, particularly in terms of bond strength and electron density distribution. Additionally, to further evaluate the thermodynamic stability of the doped structures, AIMD simulations have been conducted as provided in Fig. S1. Minimal structural deformation was observed before and after the simulation, with atoms displaying only slight vibrational movements around their equilibrium positions, without any bond breaking or significant geometric reconstruction. This conclusion is supported by the total energy analysis, which reveals energy fluctuations of less than 0.5 eV confirming the structural and energetic stability of the doped configuration under the given simulation conditions [44,45]. Furthermore, 1T-MoS2 exhibits a distinct crystal lattice characterized by precise coordination and bonding between Mo and S atoms. However, akin to other crystal structures, the introduction of dopants perturbs this arrangement by modifying the local chemical environment and electronic configuration. Notably, highly electronegative dopants C, F, N, and O have introduced additional charge carriers into the MoS2 lattice, thereby influencing the electronic band structure due to their disparate electronegativities and atomic sizes. This alteration has repercussions on the energetics and stability of various structural phases, as depicted in Fig. 3(b–f). Specifically, Fig. 3(c) illustrates that carbon C doping induces a transformation of the structural phases to the 1T’ configuration, while in the other scenarios, a 1T’ phase configuration is attained (Fig. 3d–f). This phenomenon arises from the introduction of dopants inducing strain and localized distortions in the lattice, thereby favoring the formation of energetically favorable structural configurations [46]. The phase transitions induced by doping can be beneficial for KIBs. For instance, stabilizing these phases can prevent phase transitions during cycling, thereby improving the cycling stability of the battery. Additionally, the increased interlayer spacing and enhanced electronic conductivity can improve ion diffusion kinetics and enhance the rate capability of the battery [47,48]. To gain deeper insights into the electrical characteristics of the examined configurations, energy band structures calculation has been conducted. As depicted in Fig. 4 (a), there are discernible bands intersecting the Fermi level, indicating that the monolayer 1T-MoS2 demonstrates metallic behavior. This observation aligns with previous findings [27], affirming the fidelity of the simulated electrical properties of these structures. Typically, in the context of semiconductors or insulators, the conduction band is delineated from the valence band by an energy gap. However, in metallic substances such as 1T-MoS2, a clearly delineated energy gap akin to that seen in insulators or semiconductors is absent. Instead, the onset of the conduction band immediately follows the Fermi level, where certain energy states remain unoccupied. Electrons within the conduction band possess unhindered mobility throughout the material, thus contributing to its metallic conductivity. Further, doping 1T-MoS2 with C, F, and N elements also exhibits a consistent metallic behavior in the modified structures, as shown in Fig. 4(b–d). This phenomenon can be attributed to the influence of the electronegative dopants on the structure. It is noteworthy that the likelihood of discerning distinct energy states for electrons is heightened with doping, as evidenced by the densification of the conduction band compared to the pristine structure. However, a notable transition from metallic to a somewhat semiconductive nature is observed for O-doped structures. In this scenario, the Fermi level either resides within the bandgap or in close proximity to either the conduction or valence band, rendering no available energy states for electron occupation at the Fermi level. Consequently, the material effectively assumes the semiconductor state, characterized by the substantial energy required for electron transition from the valence to conduction band, thus impairing its conductivity. Nevertheless, previous studies [49] have shown the transition from 1T to 1T’ or 1T’ leads to a shift from a metallic to a semiconductive state. However, in the doped structures mentioned, apart from the O-doped exception, the band configuration still indicates conductivity. Which suggests that the doping atoms are influencing the electronic properties of the material, potentially altering the band structure. Therefore, while the phase transition generally leads to a change in conductivity, the presence of certain dopants is counteracting this effect, allowing the material to maintain its conductivity even after the transition. As seen in Fig. 4(e), the O-doped MoS2 monolayer manifests as a direct-band-gap semiconductor, with both the valence band maximum (VBM) and conduction band minimum (CBM) situated at the Γ point. The direct band gap is determined to be 0.45 eV. Therefore, the electronic band gap undergoes a transition from metallic to direct band gap induced by O doping. Overall, compared to the pristine counterpart, significant alterations are observed in the profiles of the conduction and valence bands in the doped monolayer MoS2 systems (Fig. 4b–e). Although in the doped single-layer MoS2 systems, the overall width of the conduction bands is slightly denser than that of the pure monolayer MoS2, the availability of occupied energy states is significantly enhanced for all doping cases. To investigate the involvement of various orbitals, the projected density of states (PDOS) for both pristine and doped 1T-MoS2 monolayers was examined and shown in Fig. 5 (a–e). As illustrated in Fig. 5(a), the valence band of pristine 1T-MoS2 primarily originates from Mo-4d and S-3p orbitals, revealing a pronounced hybridization between them, indicative of the formation of robust covalent bonds between Mo and S atoms. Previous studies on transition metal dichalcogenides have revealed that the density of states near the Fermi level primarily stems from the d-orbitals of the transition metal rather than the p-orbitals of the chalcogen [35]. Moreover, the uppermost occupied valence band is predominantly characterized by Mo-4d orbitals [35,50]. In the conduction band, Mo-4d orbitals also dominate, while the contribution from S-3p orbitals remains relatively minimal. The intensity of density of states for Mo above the Fermi level indicates its partially metallic nature as a transition metal. This phenomenon can be attributed to the availability of unoccupied electronic states of Mo, facilitating bonding interactions. The introduction of highly electronegative dopants into the pristine structure resulted in a significant alteration in the density of states (DOS) configuration, primarily due to the pronounced electron affinity of the dopants. With the exception of oxygen doping, as depicted in Fig. 5(b–d), a noticeable increase in the availability of unoccupied electronic states near the Fermi level was observed, akin to an augmentation in the conductivity of the structures. Additionally, upon comparing the DOS of the doped structures, a noticeable discontinuity in the available states is observed in the range of −0.7 to −0.3 eV for the F-doped structure, along with the semi-metallic behavior of the O-doped structure. In contrast, the C-doped and N-doped 1T-MoS2 exhibit a continuous and more pronounced DOS in this energy range, attributed to the minimal yet effective contribution from the 2p states of C and N, respectively. This distinct variation arises from the significantly higher DOS near the Fermi level in the C- and N-doped structures, as shown in Fig. S2. More specifically, near the Fermi level, particularly just above 0 eV, the DOS is substantially more prominent in the C- and N-doped configurations, enhancing electron mobility and contributing to metallic behavior. In contrast, the O- and F-doped structures exhibit a near absence or negligible presence of states in this region, with the F-doped system showing reduced conductivity, indicative of a transition towards semi-metallic behavior. These differences in the DOS distributions near the Fermi level are critical in driving the contrasting electronic properties observed in these doped systems, as per band theory. Furthermore, a discernible change worth mentioning is the normalization of the two most dominant available states near the energy range of −7 and −3.5 eV in the pristine structure, which became more evenly distributed among other peaks in the doped structures. In the case of the O-doped 1T-MoS2 structure, it is surprising to note that, unlike the other electronegative atoms, O 2p orbitals exhibited minimal and negligible contributions near the Fermi level. Nevertheless, the overall electronic affinity led to a uniform distribution of states among the peaks and a sudden decline at the Fermi level, suggesting a lack of available states for electron acquisition. The distinction in DOS profiles can be further understood through the concept of electronegativity and electron acceptance ability. The underlying cause of this behavior lies in the electronegativity of the dopants: F (3.98) > O (3.44) > N (3.04) > C (2.55). Highly electronegative atoms, such as F and O, exhibit a stronger ability to withdraw electron density. This is due to their tendency to form more polar covalent bonds with neighboring Mo atoms, compared to N and C, resulting in a significant distribution of charges within the structure. F, while being the most electronegative, can accept only one electron due to its electronic configuration (2s 22p 5), leading to a semi-metallic behavior. O (2s 22p 4), however, can accept up to two electrons, allowing it to more effectively deplete electronic states near the Fermi level. This significant electron withdrawal leads to a substantial redistribution of electron density, effectively opening a bandgap and transforming the metallic 1T phase into a semiconductive nature [51]. From these perspectives, O weaker hybridization with Mo-4d compared to C and N, coupled with its high electronegativity, two available vacancies in its 2p orbital to accept electrons, results in the removal of available electronic states at the Fermi level. This unique balance of electronegativity and bonding behavior results in inducing semi-conductivity in O-doped 1T-MoS2. While the high DOS of C and N sustains metallic behavior and the weaker contribution of F maintains semi-metallic characteristics, O depletion of states near the Fermi level fully transitions the material to a semiconductive state with a direct bandgap of 0.45 eV. Except for the O-doped structure, the presence of a doped electronegative atom has a beneficial effect on extending the conduction band in all other cases, as demonstrated in Fig. S2. This indicates that the inclusion of an electronegative dopant promotes the expansion of the conduction band, thereby enhancing its conductivity. Another noteworthy aspect is that the hybridization of S-3p orbitals and Mo-4d orbitals exhibits greater strength than the hybridization of 2p orbitals of doped electronegative elements and Mo-4d orbitals. This suggests that the covalent bonds between Mo and S carry higher covalent bonding strength compared to bonding between Mo and electronegative atom. Analogous to the pristine state, the conduction bands in the doped scenarios are primarily influenced by Mo-4d and S-3p orbitals, with minimal contributions from electronegative elements. Thus, doping the pristine structure with electronegative nonmetal elements alters the electron density distribution and enhances the material's conductivity due to pronounced electron affinity of the dopants which further resulted in the conduction band remains densely populated, leading to increased electron mobility. These alterations in the electronic structure are critical as they may significantly impact the material's adsorption and desorption characteristics in metal-ion interactions, affecting its performance in catalysis and energy storage applications. Furthermore, in order to encounter the high influence of Mo-4d orbitals as observed from DOS, GGA + U method was employed to account for the strong electron-electron interactions associated with the Mo 4d orbitals [52]. To address this, a Hubbard parameter (U) value of 4 eV was applied to the Mo atoms to better describe the on-site Coulomb interactions [53]. Despite these theoretical enhancements, the results of our analysis, presented in Fig. S3, indicate that the influence of the GGA + U method on the electronic properties of the studied material is relatively minor. Specifically, the application of the U parameter results in a slight reduction in the intensity of the peaks associated with the Mo 4d states. However, it does not lead to substantial changes in the overall electronic structure, particularly in the energy states near the Fermi level, which remain largely unaffected. The limited impact of the GGA + U correction can be attributed to the system's composition, where the electronegative atoms, including S, lack of d orbitals. This absence reduces the significance of strong d-d interactions, thereby diminishing the overall effect of the Hubbard U correction in this context. To observe the impact of spin polarization, the spin polarization effect was considered in DFT calculations. It is well-established that pristine 1T-MoS2 does not exhibit significant intrinsic magnetism as per [54,55]. However, introducing magnetic dopants can induce magnetic properties. In this study, the doping percentage of electronegative elements is relatively low (approximately 3.7% atomic), and these dopants are non-magnetic. Consequently, the calculated spin-up and spin-down DOS are nearly identical and symmetrical, indicating that the impact of spin polarization on the material’s magnetic behavior is negligible. This observation aligns with Fig. S4, where no significant spin-splitting is evident. 3.2 Adsorption mechanism To investigate the interaction dynamics between K atoms and the host material, three distinct atomic locations were strategically chosen. These chosen atomic sites, illustrated in Fig. 6 (a) and denoted as P, Q, and R sites, serve as focal points for the adsorption of K content. At the P site, the atom considered varies between an S atom in the pristine structure and a dopant electronegative atom in the doped structure. This variation facilitates the simulation of the interaction between electronegative atoms and their behavior upon exposure to K atoms. Meanwhile, the Q site is positioned atop a metal Mo atom, allowing for an examination of the behavior when its outer shell electrons are being influenced by an electronegative atom. Lastly, the R site is selected to observe the impact of the S atom in the anode material. The primary criterion for selecting the optimal structure as an anode material relies heavily on the structural configuration, ensuring that the adsorption of K+ ions does not induce phase transitions of the host materials and that the anode material maintains its structural integrity [23]. To investigate this characteristic, the adsorption process on monolayer sheets has been scrutinized, as depicted in Fig. 6(b–f) and Fig. S5. Detailed examination reveals that in the case of the 1T-MoS2 layer, the adsorption of a single potassium ion triggers a phase transition from 1T to 1T’. This phenomenon is further elucidated in Fig. S6(a), illustrating how the adsorption of a single ion can induce a configurable change in bonding throughout the entire structure. Conversely, in the instances of doped structures, such phase transition phenomena are absent, as demonstrated in Fig. S6(b–e). This behavior of 1T-MoS2 renders the structure unsuitable as an anode material due to its compromised structural stability. Further, the determination of the most suitable adsorption site hinges on the adsorption energy, quantified by Eq. (1), which serves as a measure of the stability of the K atom when adsorbed onto the MoS2 surface. In the realm of adsorption, a lower adsorption energy signifies a more stable adsorption configuration, hence identifying the most stable structure entails identifying the configuration with the smallest adsorption energy. Under this consideration, a favorable reaction occurs between MoS2 and K when the adsorption energy value is negative. It is noteworthy that K bulk is chosen as the reference state. Consequently, a positive adsorption energy implies the absence of a favorable reaction between K and MoS2 in an electrochemical environment. This circumstance may pave the way for the formation of K clusters, potentially inducing dendritic crystal growth in charge/discharge processes which is not favorable for battery applications [56]. The calculated E ad resulting from the adsorption of K on distinct structures, contingent upon their target atom and site, are summarized in Table 2 . The optimized geometries representing K adsorption with the lowest E ad for the doped structures are depicted in Fig. 6(d–f). Remarkably, with the exception of the C doped structure, in all other instances, the E ad is minimized when the target atom is specified as Mo. As presented in Fig. S5, for Q-site host atoms for the case of F, N and O doped monolayers a noteworthy observation arises, wherein the K atom displays a propensity to migrate towards electronegative atoms due to their elevated electron affinity. This phenomenon accentuates the tendency of the K atom to gravitate towards electronegative atoms, resulting in the strongest bonding interactions with them. Consequently, the K atom establishes covalent bonds with the electronegative atom. As a consequence of the aforementioned behavior, the magnitude of E ad when the target atom is Mo, along with the corresponding electronegative atom in structures such as MoS2-F, MoS2-N, and MoS2-O, remains in close vicinity. Moreover, it is noteworthy to mention that the E ad remains nearly identical when the target atom is S. This observation underscores the robustness of the DFT approach, as it suggests that despite variations in atomic positions, the behavior of atoms due to their distinct nature, conforms consistently throughout the infinite sheet of the material under investigation. However, in the case of MoS2-N and MoS2-O, the K atom displays a tendency to form covalent bonds with a single and two Mo atoms, respectively. This behavior slightly deviates in the case of MoS2-C as it is solely related to C atom. In contrast, within the C doped structure, the minimal E ad of −2.611 eV is observed when K is adsorbed onto a S atom within the monolayered sheet. This deviation from the general trend may be attributed to the inherent departure from metallic behavior, as discussed in the preceding section. In the C doped structure, illustrated in Fig. 6(c), the K atom distances itself from the C atom, establishing covalent bonds with the nearest two S atoms in proximity. To further investigate the role and impact of electronegative atom doping on the structural stability of 1T-MoS2, the effects of both multiple-atom doping and the incorporation of electronegative atoms as lattice impurities were systematically analyzed, as illustrated in Figs. S7 and S8. In these studies, the electronegative atoms were strategically doped at S sites in the bottom layer of the 1T-MoS2 structure, positioned directly opposite the site of the previously doped atom. This configuration was chosen to ensure a balanced distribution of dopants within the lattice. Upon doping, notable phase transitions were observed: while the C-doped structure transformed into the 1T’ phase, other electronegative atom-doped structures transitioned to the 1T’ phase, as detailed in Fig. S7. The stability of these doped configurations was further evaluated by analyzing K+ ion adsorption on their surfaces. Except for the F- and N-doped configurations, all other doped structures exhibited phase transformations upon K+ adsorption, indicating their inability to maintain structural integrity under intercalation. This instability highlights the limitations of these configurations as potential anode materials. Notably, the adsorption energy for F- and N-doped 1T-MoS2 lattices was calculated to be +0.31 and +0.49 eV (as provided in Table S1), respectively, indicating endothermic adsorption processes. Such positive adsorption energy values suggest that external energy input is required for adsorption, reflecting a weaker natural affinity between K+ ions and the doped surfaces. Additionally, the introduction of a second electronegative atom as an impurity in the lattice structure was analyzed. A similar trend of phase transitions upon K+ adsorption was observed for C (Fig. S8a), N (Fig. S8c), and O (Fig. S8d) configurations under consideration, while F did not exhibit any bonding with either S or Mo (Fig. S8b). Depending on these claims it is clear that maintaining a doping concentration of up to 3.7% atomic of electronegative atoms in the lattice as dopant effectively prevented phase distortion during K+ ion intercalation. This finding highlights the pivotal role of controlled doping concentrations in enhancing the structural robustness of 1T-MoS2, establishing its potential as a viable anode material for KIBs. Consequently, the scope of this study has been deliberately focused on single atom doping to ensure precise evaluation of its effects. Apart from E ad, E coh parameter significantly influences the stability and structural robustness of the anode material throughout the charging and discharging cycles. In potassium-based batteries, analogous to lithium-ion batteries, the anode experiences repetitive processes of potassium insertion (during charging) and extraction (during discharging) [57]. These cycles necessitate materials with strong cohesion to endure the mechanical stresses involved [58]. The E coh dictates the thermodynamic stability and the strength of bonds within the intercalated anode material. Higher E coh implies stronger atomic bonds, which in turn enhances the material's resistance to structural degradation or disintegration during cycling. This resilience is crucial for preserving the structural integrity of the anode material over numerous charge-discharge cycles, thereby impacting the overall performance and longevity of the battery. E coh of the structures loaded with K is calculated using Eq. (2) and subsequently presented in Fig. 7 . In the context of cohesive energy, a more negative value generally indicates stronger binding within the material, which translates to enhanced resistance against structural degradation or disintegration during cycling. As shown in Fig. 7, the K adsorbed on O for MoS2-O structure exhibits the highest absolute value of cohesive energy (−0.850 eV/atom), indicating the strongest atomic bonding within the material. This suggests that the MoS2-O structure would likely offer the most robust stability and structural integrity during battery cycling among the structures investigated. The magnitude is nearly identical for the most stable doped site in the F-MoS2 structure, with E coh of −0.845 eV/atom. Therefore, from a cohesive energy standpoint, the MoS2-O structure appears to be the most favorable choice for applications in KIBs, providing greater assurance of long-term performance and durability. On the other hand, for both cases of 1T-MoS2 structure exhibits the lowest absolute value cohesive energy (−0.595 eV/atom) among the structures investigated. This implies that the atomic bonding within this structure is comparatively weaker than the others. And in turn, weak atomic bonding suggests reduced resistance to structural degradation or disintegration during battery cycles as validated in the preceding section. Building on the insights gained regarding the thermal stability of the K-adsorbed pristine and doped 1T-MoS2 structures, it becomes crucial to explore how these modifications influence the electronic structure of the material. A detailed analysis of electronic conductivity reveals subtle yet important shifts in DOS, as presented in Fig. 8 (a–d). For the C-doped structures, a slight decrease in the DOS intensity near the Fermi level indicates a transition toward semiconductive properties. However, both C- and F-doped structures exhibit minimal overall changes in DOS, with the F-doped structure demonstrating the least alteration in electronic behavior. This limited shift in electronic conductivity is attributed to the marginal contribution of the K-2p orbitals near the Fermi level, as illustrated in Fig. S9(a and d). The weak interaction between K and these structures results in diminished electron transfer, which hinders conductivity enhancement. In contrast, structures doped with N and O exhibit a pronounced leftward shift in the DOS close to the Fermi level. Notably, the O-doped structure shows a more significant shift, leading to an expansion of the conduction band and a substantial increase in conductivity. This suggests a transition from semiconductive to metallic behavior for O-doped 1T-MoS2, attributed to the substantial contribution of K-2p orbitals above the Fermi level. The presence of these orbitals facilitates the widening of the conduction band, as demonstrated in Fig. S9(d), which in turn enhances electronic conductivity through effective electron transfer from K-2p to the MoS2 framework. Thus, a detailed charge density analysis offers a clearer understanding of the charge redistribution and bonding behavior of the K atom with the surface, shedding light on how doping with electronegative atoms like C, N, O, and F alters the electronic properties of the system as illustrated in Fig. 9 . This analysis, combined with DOS calculations, reveals a clear correlation between charge transfer magnitudes and electronic behavior. As depicted in Fig. 9, the electron density is predominantly localized at the K atom site, while electron depletion is observed at the atomic bonds. This substantial charge transfer induced by K adsorption contributes to the stability of its attachment to the monolayer structure. The notable electron accumulation around the host atom where K is adsorbed signifies robust bonding with the MoS2 layer, accompanied by a loss of one electron from the K atom. The charge redistribution significantly impacts the vicinity of the adsorption site, where the host atom experiences a considerable charge transfer, which is balanced by charge redistribution from neighboring atoms. Bader charge analysis quantifies these interactions, revealing charge contributions of 0.30e, 0.85e, 0.46e, and 0.59e from the K atom to structures doped with C, N, O, and F, respectively. It is noteworthy that the charge losses associated with C and N are lower compared to those for F and O, as the latter two exhibit a tendency to donate more electrons due to their higher electronegativity. Upon adsorption onto the 1T-MoS2 monolayer, all metal atoms transition to cationic states, further indicating their interactive behavior within the layered material. The interaction of K atoms with F-doped host sites leads to substantial charge transfer from the K atom; however, this charge redistribution is confined mainly to the adsorption site. As a result, the overall stability of the monolayer remains largely unaffected post-adsorption. The minimal alterations in charge density observed in the F-doped structure imply that the electronic environment around the active sites is relatively stable. This stability is likely due to favorable bonding configurations and electronic states that optimize the adsorption and release of K, which are critical processes in the operation of batteries. In contrast, MoS2 structures doped with C, N, and O show pronounced charge redistribution upon the adsorption of K. Notably, the O-doped structure reveals extensive charge sharing across nearly all atoms, suggesting enhanced bonding interactions with the K atom. Such strong interactions can stabilize reaction intermediates, negatively affecting catalytic efficiency and kinetics in energy conversion and storage applications [59]. Additionally, the limited charge redistribution in the F-doped structure indicates that it provides an optimal binding energy for KIBs. This careful balance is essential, as it ensures that the binding energy is adequate—not too strong to impede K release, nor too weak to hinder K adsorption. Achieving this balance is crucial for maximizing catalytic performance and enhancing the efficacy of energy storage systems. 3.3 Electrochemical properties of K-intercalated monolayers When evaluating rechargeable batteries, two critical parameters to consider are the specific capacity, measured in mAh/g, and OCV. In this aspect, the charging and discharging processes of batteries utilizing the investigated configurations as anode materials can be described as follows. (6) 1 T - M o S 2 + n K + + ne - ↔ 1 T - M o S 2 - K n or M o S 2 - D + n K + + ne - ↔ M o S 2 - D - K n The adsorption process was focused on the most energetically favorable adsorption sites, after which the maximum adsorption capacity of K atoms was determined based on the stability of the resulting intercalated structure. The process involved adsorbing K atoms centered around the favorable site to assess the structural stability after each addition. It was observed that for the modified MoS2 systems, specifically MoS2-F, MoS2-N, and MoS2-C, the monolayers could accommodate up to five K atoms on the top surface without significant structural distortion, as presented in Fig. S10. In contrast, MoS2-O could only sustain up to three K atoms while maintaining its structural integrity. The stability of these configurations was further analyzed by calculating E f and E coh to assess the energetics of the adsorption process. These parameters also validated the maximum adsorption capacity of K atoms in the doped structures. As shown in Fig. 10 (a), E f trends toward zero and eventually becomes positive as K content increases, indicating the weakening of structural integrity due to intercalation. This trend explains why E f becomes positive after the addition of six K atoms in the C, F, and N-doped structures, while in the O-doped structure, it remains negative until the number of K atoms exceeds three. A similar trend is observed in E coh as presented in Fig. 10(b), where the most negative value indicates stronger bonding. As more K atoms are intercalated, E coh shifts toward less negative values, indicating weakening bonding strength and reduced structural cohesion. The transition from negative to positive values for both E f and E coh suggests that at higher levels of K intercalation, the energy required to maintain the structure increases, marking the onset of instability. This reflects the system's tendency toward instability due to over-intercalation, where excess K atoms disrupt the bonding network and introduce strain within the monolayer. To assess the feasibility of layered MoS2 as an electrode material for KIBs, we conducted an analysis of its crucial electrochemical characteristics, specifically the voltage profile determined by the Eq. (4), within the accessible concentration range of variable x , taking into account the stability of the modified structure. In general, achieving a high net cell voltage is desirable when the cathode and anode possess high and low half-cell voltages, respectively. Fig. 10(c–f) illustrates the concentration-dependent profile of the electrode potential for the doped 1T-MoS2 polytypes. Upon closer examination, it becomes evident that for lower concentrations of x , the voltage profile exhibits a wider range of variability across all the structures. The increased magnitude of the concentration-dependent voltages can be attributed to the stronger binding of K with the monolayers. By considering stable compositions, the average potentials obtained are 0.45 V for MoS2-C, 0.22 V for MoS2-F, 0.238 V for MoS2-N, and 0.245 V for MoS2-O as presented in Fig. 11 (a), falling within an anticipated potential range. Taking into account both the specific capacity and OCV, it can be concluded that among the doped structures, MoS2-F and MoS2-N exhibit superiority compared to the other two counterparts, namely MoS2-C and MoS2-O. Notably, a potential range of 0.1 to 1.0 V effectively curtails the growth of K dendrites and ensures a relatively high output voltage for the full-cell configuration [60]. As a result, the incorporation of electronegative atoms into the 1T-MoS2 structure showcases remarkable electrochemical properties for KIBs. This finding is substantiated by a comparison of average voltages with other 2D materials and even superior then previously reported pristine 2D 1T-MoS2, as presented in Table 3 , which highlights the favorable nature of electronegative atom F and N doped MoS2 as an anode material. Consequently, the observed OCV further supports the suitability of electronegative atom F and N doped 1T-MoS2 as a practical choice for implementing it as a K host in KIBs. An additional significant indication closely related to the maximum number of intercalated K ions adsorbed within the structure is the specific capacity, which determines the energy density. The specific capacity for all the modified structures has been calculated using the formula mentioned in Eq. (3) to facilitate a clear comparison between the doped structures. In this regard, MoS2-F exhibits the highest specific capacity of 339.6476 mAh/g, which is closely comparable to MoS2-N (339.1711 mAh/g) and MoS2-C (337.9852 mAh/g) as depicted in Fig. 11(b). However, due to its limited ability to adsorb K ions, MoS2-O shows the lowest specific energy of 203.2181 mAh/g, thus defining the least energy density. It should be mentioned here that the electronegative property of MoS2-C, MoS2-F, and MoS2-N not only ensure enhanced stability but also provide better energy density compared to pristine 2D 1T-MoS2 for potential anodic component of KIBs as reported in [37]. Consequently, the increased energy density exhibited by the altered MoS2 through the introduction of electronegative atoms makes them more favorable than pristine 1T-MoS2 for practical utilization as potassium hosts in KIBs. The superior OCV values observed for F and N-doped MoS2 can be attributed to their ability to introduce shallow donor states, enhance carrier density and diffusivity, and improve Fermi level alignment with the electrodes. These modifications reduce charge recombination, minimize lattice distortions, and promote efficient charge separation, ultimately contributing to higher ionic diffusion dynamics. To get a clear understanding of the ionic diffusion properties of the of the configurations, the σ values were determined using Eq. (6), revealing 6.11 mS/cm for C, 7.002 mS/cm for F, 6.978 mS/cm for N, and 6.01 mS/cm for O doped configurations. These results highlight distinct trends in how various dopants affect the material's electronic properties. The lower conductivity observed for C-MoS2 can be attributed to C bonding characteristics and electronic effects. C can form both sp 2 and sp 3 hybridized bonds, which, depending on the local environment, may result in the formation of localized bonds with Mo or S atoms. This can introduce defect states that partially trap carriers, thereby reducing their contribution to conductivity [63]. Additionally, C is less electronegative compared to F and O, which means it does not create strong electron-donating or withdrawing effects. As a result, fewer charge carriers are generated, and the delocalization of electrons in the lattice is less effective. In contrast, F and N dopants demonstrate superior performance due to their unique properties. F, being highly electronegative, enhances electron delocalization and increases carrier density while maintaining structural stability [64]. N, on the other hand, exhibits strong chemical compatibility with the MoS2 lattice, introducing shallow donor states without causing significant structural or electronic penalties. These factors collectively result in higher conductivity for F- and N-doped 1T-MoS2 compared to other dopants [65]. Although O is more electronegative than N, its stronger bonding interactions with the lattice and potential to create deeper trap states hinder its conductivity enhancement relative to N. This highlights the importance of balancing electronegativity and structural compatibility to achieve optimal electronic properties in doped 1T-MoS2 [66]. 4 Conclusions In summary, this study provides a comprehensive investigation into the potassium ion interaction within a monolayer of 1T-MoS2 that has been doped with highly electronegative atoms (C, F, N, and O) with an aim to increase the number of active sites on the surface of the material, thereby enhancing its potassiation capabilities and making it a suitable anode material for KIBs. Upon the introduction of electronegative atom doping, with the exception of the C-doped structure, all other structures transformed into the 1T’ phase, while the C-doped structure exhibited the 1T’ phase. Furthermore, all electronegative atom-doped structures exhibited superior thermal stability, as validated by AIMD simulations. Notably, compared to the pristine structures, the doped structures demonstrated superior stability in terms of phase transition, as they maintained their phase configuration even after the adsorption of potassium ions. Additionally, when considering structural robustness of the anode material throughout the charging and discharging cycles, the doped structures were proved to be a superior alternative to the pristine structure, with MoS2-O achieving an energy value of −0.850 eV/atom compared to −0.595 eV/atom for the pristine structure. Furthermore, the adsorption of K+ ions in the doped structures resulted in enhanced conductivity, particularly in the case of the two most electronegative atom-doped structures (F and O), while the other two structures exhibited semiconductive configurations. However, when considering the electrochemical properties that validate the suitability of anodic materials, the analysis of specific capacity and OCV demonstrates that MoS2-F and MoS2-N outperform the other two counterparts. These findings suggest that the F and N doped 1T-MoS2 layers hold great promise as potential anode materials for KIBs, specifically for applications in stationary energy storage. coredata.dc:description: The scarcity and high cost of lithium resources drive the search for sustainable alternatives, positioning potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) as promising energy storage solutions due to the natural abundance and advantageous electrochemical properties of the potassium. This study investigates the enhancement of KIB anodes through phase transformation and electronic structure engineering of monolayer 1T-MoS2, achieved via doping with highly electronegative non-metal elements: carbon (C), nitrogen (N), oxygen (O), and fluorine (F). Density functional theory (DFT) simulations reveal that electronegative atom doping enhances phase stability, structural robustness, and thermal resilience, which are key properties for high-performance KIB anodes. Among the doped configurations, F and N-doped 1T-MoS2 (MoS2-F and MoS2-N) exhibit superior electrochemical performance, showing optimal adsorption energies and significantly improved electronic conductivity, attributable to favorable charge redistribution and increased active potassium adsorption sites. Specifically, MoS2-F and MoS2-N achieve the highest specific capacities of 339.65 and 339.17 mAh/g, respectively, while maintaining stability within an ideal open circuit voltage range, outperforming undoped MoS2. This work underscores the potential of electronegative atom doping in 1T-MoS2 to enable sustainable, high-capacity energy storage solutions, offering key advancements in the electrochemical and structural properties of KIB anodes.

coredata.dc:title: Phase transformation and electronic structure modulation of 1T-MoS2 with electronegative non-metal doping as anode material for enhanced potassium-ion battery
